trans-unit.source: Node.js application using Socket.io | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Node.js application using Socket.io | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use socket.io in a node.js application hosted on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use socket.io in a node.js application hosted on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Socket.IO provides realtime communication between between your node.js server and clients.
trans-unit.target: Socket.IO provides realtime communication between between your node.js server and clients.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial will walk you through hosting a socket.IO based chat application on Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial will walk you through hosting a socket.IO based chat application on Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Socket.IO, see http://socket.io/.
trans-unit.target: For more information on Socket.IO, see http://socket.io/.

trans-unit.source: A screenshot of the completed application is below:
trans-unit.target: A screenshot of the completed application is below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A browser window displaying the service hosted on Azure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A browser window displaying the service hosted on Azure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Ensure that the following products and versions are installed to successfully complete the example in this article:
trans-unit.target: Ensure that the following products and versions are installed to successfully complete the example in this article:

trans-unit.source: Install <linkText>Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Install <linkText>Visual Studio 2013</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Install <linkText>Node.js</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Install <linkText>Node.js</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Install <linkText>Python version 2.7.10</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Install <linkText>Python version 2.7.10</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The following steps create the cloud service project that will host the Socket.IO application.
trans-unit.target: The following steps create the cloud service project that will host the Socket.IO application.

trans-unit.source: From the Start Menu or Start Screen, search for Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: From the Start Menu or Start Screen, search for Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Finally, right-click Azure PowerShell and select Run As Administrator.
trans-unit.target: Finally, right-click Azure PowerShell and select Run As Administrator.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure PowerShell icon</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure PowerShell icon</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Create a directory called c:\\node.
trans-unit.target: Create a directory called c:\\node.

trans-unit.source: Change directories to the c:\\node directory
trans-unit.target: Change directories to the c:\\node directory

trans-unit.source: Enter the following commands to create a new solution named chatapp and a worker role named WorkerRole1:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following commands to create a new solution named chatapp and a worker role named WorkerRole1:

trans-unit.source: You will see the following response:
trans-unit.target: You will see the following response:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The output of the new-azureservice and add-azurenodeworkerrolecmdlets</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The output of the new-azureservice and add-azurenodeworkerrolecmdlets</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For this project, we will use the chat example from the [Socket.IO GitHub repository].
trans-unit.target: For this project, we will use the chat example from the [Socket.IO GitHub repository].

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps to download the example and add it to the project you previously created.
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps to download the example and add it to the project you previously created.

trans-unit.source: Create a local copy of the repository by using the Clone button.
trans-unit.target: Create a local copy of the repository by using the Clone button.

trans-unit.source: You may also use the ZIP button to download the project.
trans-unit.target: You may also use the ZIP button to download the project.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A browser window viewing https://github.com/LearnBoost/socket.io/tree/master/examples/chat, with the ZIP download icon highlighted</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A browser window viewing https://github.com/LearnBoost/socket.io/tree/master/examples/chat, with the ZIP download icon highlighted</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Navigate the directory structure of the local repository until you arrive at the examples\\chat directory.
trans-unit.target: Navigate the directory structure of the local repository until you arrive at the examples\\chat directory.

trans-unit.source: Copy the contents of this directory to the C:\\node\\chatapp\\WorkerRole1 directory created earlier.
trans-unit.target: Copy the contents of this directory to the C:\\node\\chatapp\\WorkerRole1 directory created earlier.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Explorer, displaying the contents of the examples\\chat directory extracted from the archive</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Explorer, displaying the contents of the examples\\chat directory extracted from the archive</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The highlighted items in the screenshot above are the files copied from the examples\\chat directory
trans-unit.target: The highlighted items in the screenshot above are the files copied from the examples\\chat directory

trans-unit.source: In the C:\\node\\chatapp\\WorkerRole1 directory, delete the server.js file, and then rename the app.js file to server.js.
trans-unit.target: In the C:\\node\\chatapp\\WorkerRole1 directory, delete the server.js file, and then rename the app.js file to server.js.

trans-unit.source: This removes the default server.js file created previously by the Add-AzureNodeWorkerRole cmdlet and replaces it with the application file from the chat example.
trans-unit.target: This removes the default server.js file created previously by the Add-AzureNodeWorkerRole cmdlet and replaces it with the application file from the chat example.

trans-unit.source: Before testing the application in the Azure emulator, we must make some minor modifications.
trans-unit.target: Before testing the application in the Azure emulator, we must make some minor modifications.

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps to the server.js file:
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps to the server.js file:

trans-unit.source: Open the server.js file in Visual Studio or any text editor.
trans-unit.target: Open the server.js file in Visual Studio or any text editor.

trans-unit.source: Find the Module dependencies section at the beginning of server.js and change the line containing sio = require('..//..//lib//socket.io') to sio = require('socket.io') as shown below:
trans-unit.target: Find the Module dependencies section at the beginning of server.js and change the line containing sio = require('..//..//lib//socket.io') to sio = require('socket.io') as shown below:

trans-unit.source: To ensure the application listens on the correct port, open server.js in Notepad or your favorite editor, and then change the following line by replacing 3000 with process.env.port as shown below:
trans-unit.target: To ensure the application listens on the correct port, open server.js in Notepad or your favorite editor, and then change the following line by replacing 3000 with process.env.port as shown below:

trans-unit.source: After saving the changes to server.js, use the following steps to install required modules, and then test the application in the Azure emulator:
trans-unit.target: After saving the changes to server.js, use the following steps to install required modules, and then test the application in the Azure emulator:

trans-unit.source: Using Azure PowerShell, change directories to the C:\\node\\chatapp\\WorkerRole1 directory and use the following command to install the modules required by this application:
trans-unit.target: Using Azure PowerShell, change directories to the C:\\node\\chatapp\\WorkerRole1 directory and use the following command to install the modules required by this application:

trans-unit.source: This will install the modules listed in the package.json file.
trans-unit.target: This will install the modules listed in the package.json file.

trans-unit.source: After the command completes, you should see output similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: After the command completes, you should see output similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The output of the npm install command</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The output of the npm install command</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Since this example was originally a part of the Socket.IO GitHub repository, and directly referenced the Socket.IO library by relative path, Socket.IO was not referenced in the package.json file, so we must install it by issuing the following command:
trans-unit.target: Since this example was originally a part of the Socket.IO GitHub repository, and directly referenced the Socket.IO library by relative path, Socket.IO was not referenced in the package.json file, so we must install it by issuing the following command:

trans-unit.source: Launch the emulator by issuing the following command:
trans-unit.target: Launch the emulator by issuing the following command:

trans-unit.source: Open a browser and navigate to http://127.0.0.1.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser and navigate to http://127.0.0.1.

trans-unit.source: When the browser window opens, enter a nickname and then hit enter.
trans-unit.target: When the browser window opens, enter a nickname and then hit enter.

trans-unit.source: This will all you to post messages as a specific nickname.
trans-unit.target: This will all you to post messages as a specific nickname.

trans-unit.source: To test multi-user functionality, open additional browser windows using the same URL and enter different nicknames.
trans-unit.target: To test multi-user functionality, open additional browser windows using the same URL and enter different nicknames.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Two browser windows displaying chat messages from User1 and User2</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Two browser windows displaying chat messages from User1 and User2</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After testing the application, stop the emulator by issuing the following command:
trans-unit.target: After testing the application, stop the emulator by issuing the following command:

trans-unit.source: To deploy the application to Azure, use the Publish-AzureServiceProject cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To deploy the application to Azure, use the Publish-AzureServiceProject cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Be sure to use a unique name, otherwise the publish process will fail.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to use a unique name, otherwise the publish process will fail.

trans-unit.source: After the deployment has completed, the browser will open and navigate to the deployed service.
trans-unit.target: After the deployment has completed, the browser will open and navigate to the deployed service.

trans-unit.source: If you receive an error stating that the provided subscription name doesn't exist in the imported publish profile, you must download and import the publishing profile for your subscription before deploying to Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you receive an error stating that the provided subscription name doesn't exist in the imported publish profile, you must download and import the publishing profile for your subscription before deploying to Azure.

trans-unit.source: See the Deploying the Application to Azure section of Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service
trans-unit.target: See the Deploying the Application to Azure section of Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A browser window displaying the service hosted on Azure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A browser window displaying the service hosted on Azure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you receive an error stating that the provided subscription name doesn't exist in the imported publish profile, you must download and import the publishing profile for your subscription before deploying to Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you receive an error stating that the provided subscription name doesn't exist in the imported publish profile, you must download and import the publishing profile for your subscription before deploying to Azure.

trans-unit.source: See the Deploying the Application to Azure section of Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service
trans-unit.target: See the Deploying the Application to Azure section of Build and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Cloud Service

trans-unit.source: Your application is now running on Azure, and can relay chat messages between different clients using Socket.IO.
trans-unit.target: Your application is now running on Azure, and can relay chat messages between different clients using Socket.IO.

trans-unit.source: For simplicity, this sample is limited to chatting between users connected to the same instance.
trans-unit.target: For simplicity, this sample is limited to chatting between users connected to the same instance.

trans-unit.source: This means that if the cloud service creates two worker role instances, users will only be able to chat with others connected to the same worker role instance.
trans-unit.target: This means that if the cloud service creates two worker role instances, users will only be able to chat with others connected to the same worker role instance.

trans-unit.source: To scale the application to work with multiple role instances, you could use a technology like Service Bus to share the Socket.IO store state across instances.
trans-unit.target: To scale the application to work with multiple role instances, you could use a technology like Service Bus to share the Socket.IO store state across instances.

trans-unit.source: For examples, see the Service Bus Queues and Topics usage samples in the <linkText>Azure SDK for Node.js GitHub repository</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For examples, see the Service Bus Queues and Topics usage samples in the <linkText>Azure SDK for Node.js GitHub repository</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you learned how to create a basic chat application hosted in an Azure Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you learned how to create a basic chat application hosted in an Azure Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to host this application in an Azure Website, see <linkText>Build a Node.js Chat Application with Socket.IO on an Azure Web Site[chatwebsite]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to host this application in an Azure Website, see <linkText>Build a Node.js Chat Application with Socket.IO on an Azure Web Site[chatwebsite]</linkText><title></title>.
